message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Succinylcholine can cause extracellular potassium to shift into the intracellular space, which can lead to hyperkalemia. Given that the patient has burns covering 30% of her body, she may also be at risk for hyperkalemia due to release of potassium from damaged cells. Therefore, administration of succinylcholine during intubation can further increase the risk of hyperkalemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Succinylcholine can cause an increase in serum potassium levels, which can be dangerous in patients with burns due to the release of potassium from the damaged cells. The patient's burns are severe, covering 30% of the body, which increases the risk of hyperkalemia. Therefore, administering succinylcholine during intubation can further increase the risk of hyperkalemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Succinylcholine can cause hyperkalemia due to the depolarization of skeletal muscle cells, which can cause the release of intracellular potassium. The burns can also contribute to hyperkalemia as they can cause destruction of red blood cells and release of intracellular potassium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Administration of succinylcholine can cause an increase in potassium levels, especially in patients with burns or trauma. This condition is called hyperkalemia and can lead to respiratory muscle paralysis and cardiac arrest.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Administration of succinylcholine can cause hyperkalemia, which can increase the risk of cardiac arrest. In patients with burns, there is a loss of intracellular potassium due to cell damage, and the release of potassium from cells due to succinylcholine can exacerbate hyperkalemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Succinylcholine can cause hyperkalemia, especially in patients with burns or trauma. The patient has 30% surface area burns, which increases the risk of hyperkalemia even further.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Succinylcholine administration can cause hyperkalemia, especially in patients with burns or other forms of trauma. The patient’s burns covering 30% of her body can increase her risk of developing hyperkalemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Succinylcholine can cause depolarization of muscle fibers in patients with burns, which can lead to potassium release from damaged cells and potentially cause hyperkalemia. Therefore, administration of succinylcholine can increase the patient's risk of developing hyperkalemia, which can lead to respiratory distress. Hyperphosphatemia, hypermagnesemia, and hypernatremia are not typically associated with succinylcholine administration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Succinylcholine can cause an increase in extracellular potassium, which can lead to hyperkalemia. This is especially dangerous in patients with burns, as they are more susceptible to developing hyperkalemia due to cellular destruction and release of potassium from lysed cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Succinylcholine is known to cause hyperkalemia, especially in patients with burns or traumatic injuries. Respiratory distress following intubation may further exacerbate the risk of hyperkalemia due to acidosis and tissue damage.
